            this.ee.on(pe, v), s.on(ge, v), a.on(ge, v), this.ee.on(me, b), s.on(le, b), a.on(le, b), this.ee.buffer([pe, me, "xhr-resolved"], this.featureName), l.buffer([pe], this.featureName), c.buffer(["setTimeout" + ue, "clearTimeout" + ce, pe], this.featureName), d.buffer([pe, "new-xhr", "send-xhr" + ce], this.featureName), f.buffer([he + ce, he + "-done", he + de + ce, he + de + ue], this.featureName), h.buffer(["newURL"], this.featureName), p.buffer([pe], this.featureName), s.buffer(["propagate", ge, le, "executor-err", "resolve" + ce], this.featureName), o.buffer([pe, "no-" + pe], this.featureName), a.buffer(["new-jsonp", "cb-start", "jsonp-error", "jsonp-end"], this.featureName), y(f, he + ce), y(f, he + "-done"), y(a, "new-jsonp"), y(a, "jsonp-end"), y(a, "cb-start"), h.on("pushState-end", m), h.on("replaceState-end", m), window.addEventListener("hashchange", m, (0, C.m$)(!0, this.removeOnAbort?.signal)), window.addEventListener("load", m, (0, C.m$)(!0, this.removeOnAbort?.signal)), window.addEventListener("popstate", function () {
              m(0, i > 1);
            }, (0, C.m$)(!0, this.removeOnAbort?.signal)), this.abortHandler = this.#i, this.importAggregator();
          }
          #i() {
            this.removeOnAbort?.abort(), this.abortHandler = void 0;
          }
        }],
        loaderType: "spa"
      });
    })();
  })();
})()</script>

class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. For any questions on your own submission or other questions related to publishing an article, <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://service.elsevier.com/app/phone/supporthub/publishing\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">contact our Researcher support team.</span></span></a></p></div>","title":"What do these dates mean?"}},"glossary":{},"issueNavigation":{"previous":{},"next":{}},"linkingHubLinks":{},"metrics":{"metricGroup":{"citations":[],"captures":[],"mentions":[],"socialMedia":[]},"isLoading":false,"error":false,"hasMetrics":false},"preview":{},"rawtext":"","recommendations":{},"references":{},"referenceLinks":{"internal":[],"internalLoaded":false,"external":[]},"refersTo":{},"referredToBy":{},"relatedContent":{"isModal":false,"isOpenSpecialIssueArticles":false,"isOpenVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false,"isOpenRecommendations":true,"isOpenSubstances":true,"citingArticles":[false,false,false,false,false,false],"recommendations":[false,false,false,false,false,false]},"seamlessAccess":{},"specialIssueArticles":{},"substances":{},"supplementaryFilesData":[],"tableOfContents":{"showEntitledTocLinks":true},"tail":{},"transientError":{"isOpen":false},"sidePanel":{"openState":1},"viewConfig":{"articleFeature":{"aiNavigation":true},"pathPrefix":""},"virtualSpecialIssue":{"showVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false},"usageProps":{"itemStage":"S300","isAip":false,"tombAip":"0","sample":false},"userCookiePreferences":{"STRICTLY_NECESSARY":true,"PERFORMANCE":true,"FUNCTIONAL":true,"TARGETING":false}};

class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Due to its stability and low cost, the tunnel-style sodium-manganese oxide (Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>) material is deemed a popular cathode choice for sodium-ion rechargeable batteries. However, the Jahn-Teller effect caused by Mn<sup>3+</sup> in the material results in poor capacity and cycling stability. The purpose of this experimental study is to partially replace Mn<sup>3+</sup> with Fe<sup>3+</sup>, in order to reduce the Jahn-Teller effect of the material during charging and discharging process. The results of Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy confirmed that the content of Mn<sup>3+</sup> decreased after Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping. Electrochemical studies show that the Na<sub>0.44</sub>Mn<sub>0.994</sub>Fe<sub>0.006</sub>O<sub>2</sub> cathode has better rate performance (exhibits a reversible capacity of 87.9 mAh/g at 2 C) and cycle stability in sodium-ion batteries. The diffusion coefficient of sodium ions increases by Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping. The excellent rate performance and capacity improvement are verified by density functional theory (DFT) calculation. After doping, the band gap decreases significantly, and the results show that the state density of O 2p increases near the Fermi level, which promotes the oxidationâ€“reduction of oxygen. This work provides a straightforward approach to enhance the performance of Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> nanorods, and this performance improvement has guiding significance for the design of other materials in the energy storage domain.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005">Synthesis of Na<sub>0.44</sub>Mn<sub>1-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> with reduced Jahn-Teller effect.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0055"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (240KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (240KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724001528"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724002133"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Cathode material</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Iron doping</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> nanorods</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>First principles</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010"><span>The extraction and consumption of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a> have led to the vigorous development and application of new energy, which in turn requires strong support from energy storage methods </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>. Among various energy storage methods, electrochemical energy storage represents as the most straightforward and most efficient, thus emerging as the mainstream energy storage technology development <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>. In recent years, with the vigorous growth of the electric vehicle market <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, lithium-ion batteries as vehicle power have received unprecedented attention <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>. However, lithium reserves on the Earth are limited (the content in the crust is only about 0.0065&nbsp;%), so they cannot meet the needs of large-scale applications <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about Sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium</a> (Na), which is in the same family as lithium (Li) </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, exhibits similar physical and chemical properties to Li, and is abundant on the earth (2.74&nbsp;% in the crust) and evenly distributed <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a><span>. In the past decade, great efforts have been attributed to the rise of <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), such as carbons, alloys, etc. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a><span>. At present, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> of SIBs mainly include polyanionic materials </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, Prussian blue analogues <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, organic compounds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a><span>, tunnelled <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a><span>, and layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a><span>. In <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/manganese-oxide" title="Learn more about manganese oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">manganese oxide</a> materials (Na</span><em><sub>x</sub></em>MnO<sub>2</sub>), the structure of the material belongs to tunnel structure if the&nbsp;<em>x</em>&nbsp;value between 0.22 and 0.66. Among them, the tunnel type Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub><span> is considered the most promising cathode material for SIBs due to its <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> under low voltage </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">However, in the nonlinear MnO<sub>6</sub> octahedral field of Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>MnO<sub>2</sub> materials, Mn<sup>3+</sup> typically exists in a high-spin state, which endows it with a huge magnetic moment. The presence of this high-spin state results in a linearly elongated arrangement of MnO<sub>2</sub>. Additionally, the Mn<sup>3+</sup><span> ion in the high-spin state has only one electron in the doubly degenerate Eg orbit, leading to asymmetric <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-distribution" title="Learn more about electron distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron distribution</a>. Therefore, electrons on the end of the orbit exhibit different shielding effects on the Mn nuclear in different directions. To stabilize the Mn</span><sup>3+</sup> ion, two longitudinal Mn-O bonds are stretched, while four transverse Mn-O bonds are compressed. This stretching and compression of bonds ultimately gives rise to the Jahn-Teller(JT) effect<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. Due to the influence of the JT effect on the Mn<sup>3+</sup> ions in the octahedral structure, the crystal structure changes over time, resulting in capacity loss. Currently, the commonly-used modification methods involve doping with other elements <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, coating, and the chemical presodium method <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>. The widely used coating material selection can choose a conductor with strong conductivity (such as Graphene <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a><span>, etc.), a strongly <a href="/topics/materials-science/conductive-material" title="Learn more about conductive material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conductive material</a> (such as CNT coating </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, etc.), or a multi-functional material (such as Na<sub>2</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, etc.). There are also Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, which inhibits surface oxygen loss, and In<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, which is similar to its structure. The doping of different elements can have different main effects, and various elements can also be used to play a synergistic role. At present, the doped elements are concentrated in Ni <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, Co <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, Ti <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, Li <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, etc., and there is F <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a><span><span><span> doping on the oxygen site. They have the characteristics of increasing specific capacity and stabilizing <a href="/topics/materials-science/materials-structure" title="Learn more about material structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material structure</a>. The type, proportion, and position of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/semiconductor-doping" title="Learn more about doping elements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">doping elements</a> will affect the structure of the material, in turn its conductivity, discharge capacity, and cycling performance. In the periodic table of chemical elements, iron is adjacent to manganese, with only one difference in the number of electrons in the outer layer, demonstrating similar properties. Therefore, Fe doped manganese has the potential to improve the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of Na</span><sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> materials.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">In this paper, Fe-doped Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode materials (Na<sub>0.44</sub>Mn<sub>1-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub>) for SIBs were synthesized by the solâ€“gel method. The effects of Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping on the structure, morphology, and electrochemical performance of the samples were investigated. The results show that Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping can reduce the ratio of Mn<sup>3+</sup> to Mn<sup>4+</sup> in the material. The JT effect caused by the tensile contraction of two longitudinal Mn-O bonds and four transverse Mn-O bonds is inhibited. The electrochemical kinetic properties of the material were efficiently improved. It is not only improves the capacity but also has good rate performance and cycle stability. Based on the analysis of the data results, it can be concluded that the Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping has a significant positive impact on enhancing the charge storage capability of this type of material. It also provides an effective method for suppressing the JT effect.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials Synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0025">Taking CH<sub>3</sub>COONaâ‹…3H<sub>2</sub>O (99.0&nbsp;%), MnC<sub>4</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>â‹…4H<sub>2</sub>O (99.0&nbsp;%), and Fe(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>â‹…9H<sub>2</sub>O (98.0&nbsp;%) as raw materials, with the solâ€“gel method, tunnel-type (<em>T</em>-type) Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> materials with different amounts of Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping and the undoped sample were prepared. Firstly, we weigh a certain amount of CH<sub>3</sub>COONaâ‹…3H<sub>2</sub>O, MnC<sub>4</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>â‹…4H<sub>2</sub>O, Fe(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>â‹…9H<sub>2</sub><span>O, dissolve them in an appropriate amount of distilled water, and then mix and stir. Due to the loss of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> during sintering, we took an excess stoichiometric ratio of 10&nbsp;% CH</span><sub>3</sub>COONaâ‹…3H<sub>2</sub>O for weighing. Other reagents are weighed according to stoichiometric ratios. Then, 2&nbsp;mol/L C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>8</sub>O<sub>7</sub>â‹…H<sub>2</sub><span>O solution is added for chelation. After the pH of the mixture is adjusted to 6.5. A transparent gel was obtained by a stirring (temperature 80 Â°C, duration 4&nbsp;h). The formed gel is freeze-dried to obtain the complete precursor substance. Finally, the anionic <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> is decomposed by heating in a muffle oven for 8&nbsp;h at 350&nbsp;Â°C. The obtained powder was calcined in air at 800 Â°C in a Muffle furnace for 9&nbsp;h to obtain the final product. Both burnts are conducted in an air atmosphere. In comparison, a similar method was adopted to synthesize Na</span><sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> materials without an iron source. For convenience, the Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>0.44</sub>[<em>Mn</em><sub>0.994</sub><em>Fe</em><sub>0.006</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>0.44</sub>[<em>Mn</em><sub>0.988</sub><em>Fe</em><sub>0.012</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>0.44</sub>[<em>Mn</em><sub>0.95</sub><em>Fe</em><sub>0.05</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> are referred to as NMO, NMOF-1, NMOF-2, and NMOF-3, respectively. The manufacturing process, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr1.jpg" height="335" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (349KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (349KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic diagram of the Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> production process.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Structure of as-prepared materials has been investigated by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu KÎ± radiation (Î»&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Ã…) with the 2Î¸ range from 10Â° to 65Â° on TD-3500 <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/field-emission-scanning-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about Field emission scanning electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Field emission scanning electron microscopy</a><span> (FESEM, Zeiss sigma300) equipped with an Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS, Oxford Xplore30) was employed to observe the morphology and element distribution of the samples at an accelerating voltage of 5&nbsp;kV, to detect whether they were uniform. And the high-resolution <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a><span> (HRTEM, FEI, tecnai F2) operated at 200&nbsp;kV. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> were recorded with the Senterra microscope (RIGAKU) using a 532&nbsp;nm laser in working electrode form. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alph, America) was employed to perform the distribution of the elements on the surface of the materials.</span></span></span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>The active material was mixed with acetylene black and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a> fluoride (PVDF) in a weight ratio of 8:1:1 in a mortar and blended well. Then, a suitable amount of </span><em>n</em><span>-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution was added dropwise to evenly disperse the mixture, which was then coated onto <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminum foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum foil</a> to form the cathode electrode. The aluminum foil was then cut into 14&nbsp;mm diameter disks using a slicer, with an active mass loading of approximately 2.1&nbsp;mgâ‹…cm</span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span>. A Whatman glass fiber membrane (GF/D) was used as the separator. The electrolyte was a mixture of 1:1&nbsp;vol% ethylene carbonate (EC) and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/propylene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate (PC), with a concentration of 1.0&nbsp;M NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span>. These materials were evaluated in coin cells (2032) using sodium as the counter electrode. Coin-type cells were assembled in a glovebox filled with argon gas, with water and oxygen levels below 0.1&nbsp;ppm. The neware CT4008 battery testing system was used to evaluate the rate capability and cycling performance at 2.0 to 4.0&nbsp;V at room temperature. The CHI660E electrochemical workstation was used to perform <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) evaluation in the frequency range of 10</span><sup>5</sup> to 10<sup>âˆ’3</sup> Hz with an AC amplitude of 5&nbsp;mV, and cyclic voltammetry (CV) testing between 2.0 and 4.0&nbsp;V.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Computational method</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span><span>The Vienna Ab Initio Package (VASP) was employed to perform all the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> calculations within the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/generalized-gradient-approximation" title="Learn more about generalized gradient approximation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">generalized gradient approximation</a> (GGA) using the Perdew, Burke, and Enzerhof (PBE) formulation</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a><span>. The projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials were applied to describe the ionic cores and take valence electrons into account using a plane wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450&nbsp;eV. Partial occupancies of the Kohnâ€“Sham orbitals were allowed using the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/gaussian-distribution" title="Learn more about Gaussian from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Gaussian</a> smearing method and a width of 0.05&nbsp;eV. The electronic energy was considered self-consistent when the energy change was more minor than 10</span><sup>âˆ’6</sup> eV. A geometry optimization was considered convergent when the force change was smaller than 0.03&nbsp;eV/Ã…. Grimmeâ€™s DFT-D3 methodology was used to describe the dispersion interactions<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about Brillouin zone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Brillouin zone</a> integral utilized the surface structures of 1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;2&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;2 monkhorst pack K-point sampling.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045">The NMO and several groups of NMO samples with different Fe doping amounts have been prepared by the solâ€“gel method with the advantages of the small particle size. The XRD patterns of synthesized samples with different doping ratios are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>A. It is evident that all samples exhibit similar diffraction profiles to the NMO, corresponding to the phases of tunnel structure (JCPDS: 27â€“0750 and JCPDS: 27â€“0749) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. The main phase of four samples is Na<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>9</sub>O<sub>18</sub>, and the space group is <em>Pbam</em> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a><span>. All samples have sharp peaks and high diffractometry. The diffraction peak intensity of the NMOF-1 sample is significantly enhanced compared with that of the pristine NMO. This indicates that the sample has a higher <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a>. Nevertheless, when Fe content reached 5&nbsp;%, a tow addition diffraction peak appeared at 15.53Â° (2Î¸) and 43.44Â° (2Î¸) in the NMOF-3, corresponding to the peak of layered P2-type Na</span><sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, indicating the occurrence of phase transformation from <em>T</em>-type to P2-type layered structure <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>B shows the crystal structure of NMO. The skeleton is built on the MnO<sub>5</sub> pyramid and the MnO<sub>6</sub> octahedron <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. Mn3, Mn5, and Mn4 are occupied by Mn<sup>4+</sup>, while Mn2 and Mn1 are occupied by Mn<sup>3+</sup><span>, showing an orderly arrangement of charges. The two polyhedra are interconnected by sharing angles to form two types of 3D tunnels. One type of tunnel is the large S-shaped tunnel, which is half-filled with <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Another type is a small pentagon tunnel completely occupied by Na ions. The small S-shaped tunnels are filled with Na<sup>+</sup>, but this portion of Na<sup>+</sup> is challenging to unplug, thus leading to low specific capacity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>C shows the crystal structure of Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>. The phase of Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> belongs to the P2/O3 mixed phase, which is spontaneously converted into P2 or O3 single-phase and unstable during the electrochemical process. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. The oxygen atoms in the crystal are closely arranged in the form of hexagonal, dense packing. The transition metal Mn is distributed in the octahedral voids of O to form a solid MnO<sub>2</sub> layer<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. Na<sup>+</sup> occupies the emptiness of the triangular prism between the layers. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>D shows the model diagram for assembling the positive electrode plate into a battery. During the charging process, the positive electrode is oxidized, and Na<sup>+</sup> is separated from the NMO. During the discharge process, the positive electrode is reduced, and Na<sup>+</sup> is embedded in the positive electrode material <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr2.jpg" height="393" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (481KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (481KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(A) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of Na</span><sub>0.44</sub>Mn<sub>1âˆ’x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>2</sub> with&nbsp;x&nbsp;from 0 to 0.05. (B) Crystal structure diagram of Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0335" name="bb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>. (C) Crystal structure diagram of Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. (D) Diagram of assembled sodium-ion battery model.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050">The SEM and length profiles of the pristine NMO, NMOF-1, NMOF-2, and NMOF-3 are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>. As is seen from the figure, they display a similar rod-shaped morphology with an average length of 1â€“8&nbsp;Î¼m. After doping, the particle size becomes more uniform, among which the NMOF-1 sample having the smallest particle size and the most uniform distribution. The pure tunnel NMO and P2-layered Na<sub>0.7</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> exhibited rod-like and plate-like morphologies, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. From the SEM results, it can be seen that the plate particles begin to appear in the NMOF-3 sample, indicating that the layered structure began to appear when the doping amount is 5&nbsp;%. HRTEM images show that the lattice stripe spacing of the NMOF-1 material (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>G) and the undoped NMO material (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>C and 4D) are 0.457&nbsp;nm and 0.454&nbsp;nm, respectively, both of which can point to the (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) plane of the tunneled NMO <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a><span>. The interlayer spacing increases after doping <a href="/topics/materials-science/iron-ion" title="Learn more about Fe ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fe ions</a> into the </span><em>T</em><span>-type NMO framework. This may be attributed to the stronger <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrostatics" title="Learn more about electrostatic force from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic force</a> of Fe</span><sup>3+</sup> ions compared to Mn<sup>3+</sup><span> ions, which pulls the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxygen-ion" title="Learn more about oxygen ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen ions</a><span> closer to the transition <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a>. As a result, the Mn-O bond length in the polyhedron is shortened </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a><span>, and the bond energy of the Mn-O has risen, thereby the tunnel space for sodium ions to shuttle in the crystal is increased. In addition, the selected area <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) of NMOF-1 indicates that the sample has good crystallinity and excellent single-crystal properties (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>H). Representative SEM images of NMOF-1 samples and corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping images show that the four elements are uniformly distributed in NMOF-1 sample (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>I). It also shows that iron is successfully doped into the NMO material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr3.jpg" height="451" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. SEM images and length profile of the as prepared NMO(A), NMOF-1(B), NMOF-2(C), NMOF-3(D) materials.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr4.jpg" height="773" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(A, B) TEM images of the as-prepared NMO; (C, D) <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a><span> images of the as-prepared NMO; (E, F) TEM images of the as-prepared NMOF-1. (G, H) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> and </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> images of the as-prepared NMOF-1. (I) EDS images of the prepared NMOF-1 material.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0045"><h3 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0055">The extraction and insertion properties of NMO are investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(A-F) shows the CV and dQ/dV curves of four sample electrodes. It can be seen from the curves that the doped and undoped samples have similar redox pairs. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>B shows the CV curve of the NMOF-1 electrode. In the range of 2.0&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;4.0&nbsp;V potential, there are at least seven pairs of symmetric redox peaks (2.24&nbsp;V, 2.51&nbsp;V, 2.72&nbsp;V, 3.03&nbsp;V, 3.13&nbsp;V, 3.29&nbsp;V, and 3.50&nbsp;V, respectively) that can be observed during the whole process of sodium ion insertion and extraction. During the insertion and extraction of sodium ions in the NMO lattice, the coupling between the order of sodium and charge (at the manganese sites) results in the sodium ions entering different places (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>(A-D)), producing a multi-phase transition mechanism, which is why multiple pairs of complex <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> and reduction peaks can be observed in the CV curve </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. It is noteworthy that even the sodium ions in the small pentagonal tunnel, which were initially challenging to extract during charging and discharging to provide capacity, can now more easily shuttle in the crystal after modification, further improving the capacity of the material <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a><span>. Also, the larger area enclosed by the CV profile indicates the higher capacity released. The large CV area of NMOF-1 confirms the result of its sizeable specific capacity. However, NMOF-2 and NMOF-3 have six pairs of redox peaks. This may be due to excessive iron content, which inhibits the shuttling of sodium ions at the Na1 and Na2 sites. The intensity of the NMOF-3 redox peaks is significantly reduced. This may be due to the presence of the P2 phase. This corresponds to the SEM results. In addition, for all four samples, the cyclic voltammograms of the first cycle do not overlap as much with the subsequent two cycles, particularly at the reduction peak around 3.1&nbsp;V, indicating the presence of a certain degree of irreversible reaction during the first cycle. However, the redox peak of the NMOF-1 electrode did not change significantly in the last two cycles, demonstrating the charging and discharging process is stable. The strong peak in the first anodic cycle is attributed to the initial multi-atomic phase transition that occurs as sodium ions adapt to <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-strain" title="Learn more about structural strain from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural strain</a> during their extraction and insertion from the lattice of the electrode material. As the number of cycles increases, the oxidation and reduction peaks overlap, indicating good reversibility of the structural deformation process. The test results further demonstrate that NMOF-1 exhibits enhanced curve overlap in subsequent cycles of the cyclic voltammetry test, superior charge/discharge performance, and improved cycling stability compared to the pristine NMO. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(E-H) shows the dQ/dV curves of the fifth cycle. From the images, it can be seen that the potential interval (Î”V) between the redox peaks of NMOF-1 material is the smallest, which indicates that NMOF-1 has the least polarization among the four samples.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr5.jpg" height="980" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (812KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (812KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (A, B, C, D) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of NMO (A), NMOF-1 (B), NMOF-2 (C), NMOF-3 (D) electrode for the first three cycles between 2.0 and 4.0&nbsp;V (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;3); (E, F, G, H) dQ/dV curves of NMO (E), NMOF-1 (F), NMOF-2 (G), NMOF-3 (H) electrode for the fifth cycle (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;3).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">The electrochemical performances of the materials are evaluated by conducting constant current chargeâ€“discharge testing within the voltage range of 2.0 to 4.0&nbsp;V at rates of 0.1 C to 3 C. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(A-D) show the 10th, 20th, and 30th chargeâ€“discharge curves of four samples at a rate of 0.5 C. It can be seen that NMOF-1 sample and undoped sample have similar charge and discharge curves, and there are seven charge and discharge voltage platforms, corresponding to seven pairs of redox peaks in the CV curve <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>. With the increase in doping amounts, the charging and discharging platforms gradually become smoother. It is shown that doping can disarrange Mn/Fe, break the charging order and Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy order, and promote the double-phase reaction kinetics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a><span>. Among them, NMOF-1 material has the highest discharge capacity and recombination degree, indicating that NMOF-1 material has the best <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> during the chargeâ€“discharge process. It is worth noting that the NMOF-2 material has the largest specific charging capacity, indicating that more Na ions can be released from the orthogonal lattice. However the coincidence degree of the curves is the worst, and the corresponding specific discharge capacity is not ideal. This may be due to the excessive release of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> from the lattice during the battery charging process, resulting in the collapse of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/materials-structure" title="Learn more about material structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material structure</a>. Therefore, Na</span><sup>+</sup> are difficult to insert into the lattice during the discharge process.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr6.jpg" height="582" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (680KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (680KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (A, B, C, D) Chargeâ€“Discharge profiles for the 10th, 20th and 30th cycle of NMO (A), NMOF-1(B), NMOF-2(C), and NMOF-3 (D) at a rate of 0.5 C (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;3); (E, F) The comparison graphs of cyclic performance at 0.1 C (E) and 0.5 C (F) magnifications (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;3); (G, H) Comparison of discharge capacity before and after cycle; (I) Rate performance of four samples (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;3).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>E and 6F show the cycling performances of the four sample electrodes at 0.1 C and 0.5 C. The cycling performances of all doped samples are better than that of undoped sample when cycling at a rate of 0.1 C. The cyclic performances of NMOF-2 and NMOF-3 samples are approximately equivalent to that of undoped sample when cycling at a rate of 0.5 C. As can be seen that the NMOF-1 electrode reveals the highest initial discharging capacity (123.5 mAh/g (0.1 C), 104.0 mAh/g (0.5 C)) and maximum capacity retention (72&nbsp;% (0.1 C, 100 cycles), 65&nbsp;% (0.5 C, 200 cycles) at both 0.1 and 0.5 C, while the undoped sample has the lowest value. The comparison of discharge capacity before and after the cycle is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>G and 6H. Compared with the pristine NMO, NMOF-1 has higher specific discharge capacity and better cyclic stability, consistent with the results of the chargeâ€“discharge curve. Therefore, an appropriate amount of Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping can significantly improve the cyclic performance of the material. On the other hand, due to the expansion and contraction of the lattice during Na<sup>+</sup><span> shuttling, the volume continuously changes during charging or discharging. In the battery cycling process, this significant volume change may be due to the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/jahn-teller-effect" title="Learn more about JT effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">JT effect</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. The doping of Fe<sup>3+</sup> ions in Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> particles may help to inhibit the JT effect of the material, thereby improving the stability of the crystal structure during the cycle.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>I shows the rate performance of the four sample electrodes. It can be observed that the rate performance of the doped materials is superior to that of the undoped sample when the iron content is less than 5&nbsp;%. This may be due to the presence of highly conductive substances (iron), which increase the conductivity of electrons. On the other hand, the small size particles are more beneficial to the diffusion of Na ions and the conductivity of electrons due to the reduction of diffusion pathways, which were confirmed by the SEM analysis. However, when the doping amount reaches 5&nbsp;%, the rate performance significantly decreases, which may be due to the presence of the P2 phase reducing the conductivity of the NMO materials. As the rate value increases, the capacity decay of NMOF-1 is significantly improved than that of the pristine NMO. In particular, at a large magnification of 3 C, the discharge capacity of the NMOF-1 sample can still maintained at 79.1 mAh/g, while the pristine NMO sample is 69.9 mAh/g. After recovering to 0.1 C, the capacity of the NMOF-1 sample can recover to 92.3 mAh/g, while the pristine NMO sample is only 83.1 mAh/g.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">To further explore the influence of iron doping on the structural evolution of cathode material, we conducted XRD tests on the materials during charge and discharge processes, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>A and 7B. The results show that all diffraction peaks shift significantly to a higher 2Î¸ angle after the initial charging process, indicating Na<sup>+</sup> extraction from the Na<sub>0.44</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> skeleton and cell contraction. When discharged, the peak returns to a lower angle and even lower degree relative to the original condition, which is due to more Na<sup>+</sup> being injected into the frame rather than removed. In the process of charge and discharge, the peaks of NMOF-1 are less shifted to the left and right. This corresponds to smaller volume changes and enhanced structural stability during sample charging and discharging. This result further confirms that moderate Fe<sup>3+</sup> doping can improve the structural stability of the material, which is consistent with the previous XRD and cyclic performance results.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr7.jpg" height="699" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (667KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (667KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724001838-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of NMO (A) and NMOF-1 (B) during first round charge and discharge at 0.5 C.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0050"><h3 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. First principles calculations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">To gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism of Fe doping, DFT calculations are introduced to evaluate the effect of Fe doping on NMO conductivity. Models of the pristine NMO and NMOF-1 are constructed, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> A and 8B. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> C and 8 D show the band structures of Na<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>9</sub>O<sub>18</sub> and Na<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>9</sub>O<sub>18</sub><span><span>-Fe. As can be seen from the figures, since the upper valence band and the sole <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a> at the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fermi-surface" title="Learn more about Fermi surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi surface</a> do not overlap in K-space, the materials before and after doping are indirect band-gap semiconductors </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. Bound electrons in the valence band must undergo a different band gap (Eg) in order to transition to the conduction band <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. The smaller the band gap, the easier it is for electrons to transition and thus conduct electricity better. The results show that the band gaps of Na<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>9</sub>O<sub>18</sub> and Na<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>9</sub>O<sub>18</sub>-Fe are 1.261&nbsp;eV and 0.183&nbsp;eV, respectively. After iron doping, the band gap is obviously reduced. The reduced band gap effectively reduces the electron migration energy barrier, which makes the material more conductive, thus improving the rate performance of the material. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>E and 8F show the DOS curves of the materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>. A replacement level triggered by Fe substitution appears near the Fermi level, the band gap between the discrete valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) decreases, and the electron conductivity increases <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a><span><span>, corresponding to the result of the energy band.
